Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
One summer evening in 335 BCE, 
Alexander the Great was resting by the Danube River after 
a day of fighting the Scythian tribes when a band of strangers 
approached his camp. Alexander had never seen anything 
like these tall, fierce-looking warriors with huge 
golden neck rings and colorful cloaks— so he invited them to feast with him. They proudly said they were Keltoi 
or Celts who came from the far-away Alps. Alexander asked what they feared 
the most in the world, hoping they would say him. They laughed and said they feared 
nothing at all. This is one of the earliest stories 
about the ancient Celts. While we don’t know 
where the first Celts came from, by Alexander’s time 
they had spread across Europe from Asia Minor in the east to Spain and the Atlantic islands of Britain 
and Ireland in the west. The Celts were never one unified empire,
and they didn’t build cities or monuments. Instead, they were hundreds of independent
tribes who spoke the same language. Each had its own warrior-king 
and religious center. The tribes fought each other as enthusiastically as they fought 
their enemies. Few armies could stand up to them. Somewhat unusually for the time, 
the Celts believed in reincarnation— that they would be reborn on Earth 
to live and feast and fight again, which may have contributed 
to their fearlessness in battle. Some of them fought naked, 
scoffing at their enemies’ armor. The greatest trophy a Celtic warrior
could possess was the severed head of a foe. They preserved these heads 
in jars of cedar oil and showed them to guests 
who visited their homes. Celtic warriors were so valued 
in the ancient world that foreign kings often hired 
them as mercenary soldiers to serve in their armies. But the Celts were much more 
than just warriors. Among them were many skilled craftsmen,
artists, and great poets called bards. The bards sang of the brave deeds 
of their ancestors and praised the accomplishments
of warrior kings— and composed biting satires 
about cowardly or selfish leaders. The Celts worshipped many gods, and priests known as druids 
oversaw this worship. Anyone could become a druid, but the training required many years 
of study and memorization— the druids were not allowed to record
any of their teachings in writing. Druids supervised religious practices 
and sacrifices to the gods, but they were also teachers, healers, 
judges, and scientists. They were so respected that they could
step between warring tribes in the middle of a battle 
and call an end to the fighting. No Celt would dare to harm a druid,
or question their decisions. In the 2nd century BCE, the Romans 
began to encroach on Celtic territory, conquering the tribes of northern Italy. Rather than unite against the Roman 
legions in response to this defeat, the Celts maintained 
their tribal divisions. The tribes of Spain fell soon after. In the 1st century BCE, Julius Caesar 
marched his armies across France, using bribery, threats, and lies 
to turn tribes against each other. Only in the closing days of this great war did the Celts unite 
against their common enemy under the leadership 
of king Vercingetorix, but it was too late. Countless warriors and their families 
died or were enslaved as the Romans conquered France. Protected by the surrounding waters, the Celtic tribes of Britain and Ireland
were the last holdouts. When the Romans finally invaded Britain, the queen Boudicca united her tribe 
in a revolt after her husband was killed. She almost succeeded in driving 
the Roman legions out of Britain before dying as she led a final battle 
against the enemy. By the end of the 1st century CE, 
Ireland alone, far out at sea, remained unconquered by Rome. There, the ways of the ancient Celts 
survived untouched by the outside world long after Rome itself lay in ruins.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Celts Alexander the Great met said they feared
Options: A. They would die fighting him, B. The earth would swallow them up, C. Nothing, D. The Romans would conquer them
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Alexander the Great resting when a band of strangers approached his camp in 335 BCE? Options: A. By the Danube River, B. In the Alps, C. In Asia Minor, D. On the Atlantic islands of Britain and Ireland Correct Option: A
Question 2: What did the Celts believe in that may have contributed to their fearlessness in battle? Options: A. The power of their gods, B. The strength of their warrior-kings, C. Reincarnation, or being reborn on Earth to live and fight again, D. The importance of preserving the heads of their enemies Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the role of the bards in Celtic society? Options: A. They were skilled craftsmen and artists, B. They were great poets who sang of the brave deeds of their ancestors and praised the accomplishments of warrior kings, C. They were druids who oversaw worship and supervised religious practices, D. They were mercenary soldiers who fought in foreign armies Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the significance of the severed head of a foe to a Celtic warrior? Options: A. It was a symbol of their strength and bravery, B. It was a trophy that they preserved in jars of cedar oil and showed to guests, C. It was a reminder of their fearlessness in battle, D. It was a way to honor their ancestors Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did the druids supervise religious practices and sacrifices to the gods? Options: A. They recorded their teachings in writing and passed them down to future generations, B. They memorized their teachings and passed them down orally, C. They used their knowledge of science and healing to guide their decisions, D. They relied on the guidance of the warrior-kings Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the outcome of the Roman conquest of France in the 1st century BCE? Options: A. The Celts united under the leadership of king Vercingetorix and defeated the Romans, B. The Celts maintained their tribal divisions and were conquered by the Romans, C. The Romans were driven out of France by the Celtic tribes, D. The Celts and Romans formed an alliance and coexisted peacefully Correct Option: B
Question 7: Who united her tribe in a revolt against the Roman legions in Britain? Options: A. Queen Boudicca, B. King Vercingetorix, C. Alexander the Great, D. Julius Caesar Correct Option: A
Question 8: What was the result of the Roman invasion of Britain, and how did it affect the Celtic tribes? Options: A. The Celts were able to drive the Romans out and maintain their independence, B. The Romans conquered Britain, but the Celtic tribes were able to preserve their way of life, C. The Romans conquered Britain, and many Celtic warriors and their families died or were enslaved, D. The Celts and Romans formed an alliance and coexisted peacefully Correct Option: C
Question 9: Which of the following best describes the social structure of the ancient Celts? Options: A. They were a unified empire with a single ruler, B. They were hundreds of independent tribes with their own warrior-kings and religious centers, C. They were a nomadic people with no fixed settlements or social hierarchy, D. They were a matriarchal society with women holding positions of power Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the significance of Ireland's geographical location in terms of its relationship with the Roman Empire? Options: A. It made Ireland vulnerable to Roman conquest, B. It allowed Ireland to remain unconquered by Rome due to its isolation, C. It facilitated trade and cultural exchange between Ireland and Rome, D. It led to Ireland becoming a Roman province Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that has a similar theme and intent.

The ground truth MCQ asks about what the Celts Alexander the Great met said they feared. The correct answer is "Nothing".

Among the generated MCQs, Question 2 is the most similar in terms of theme and intent. It asks about what the Celts believed in that may have contributed to their fearlessness in battle. The correct answer is "Reincarnation, or being reborn on Earth to live and fight again". While this question does not directly ask about what the Celts feared, it is related to their fearlessness, which is a consequence of their belief in reincarnation.

However, I must note that this is not an exact match, and the generated MCQs do not directly address the question of what the Celts feared.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that Question 2 is the most similar generated MCQ, but with the caveat that it's not an exact match.

**Transcript**:
One summer evening in 335 BCE, 
Alexander the Great was resting by the Danube River after 
a day of fighting the Scythian tribes when a band of strangers 
approached his camp. Alexander had never seen anything 
like these tall, fierce-looking warriors with huge 
golden neck rings and colorful cloaks— so he invited them to feast with him. They proudly said they were Keltoi 
or Celts who came from the far-away Alps. Alexander asked what they feared 
the most in the world, hoping they would say him. They laughed and said they feared 
nothing at all. This is one of the earliest stories 
about the ancient Celts. While we don’t know 
where the first Celts came from, by Alexander’s time 
they had spread across Europe from Asia Minor in the east to Spain and the Atlantic islands of Britain 
and Ireland in the west. The Celts were never one unified empire,
and they didn’t build cities or monuments. Instead, they were hundreds of independent
tribes who spoke the same language. Each had its own warrior-king 
and religious center. The tribes fought each other as enthusiastically as they fought 
their enemies. Few armies could stand up to them. Somewhat unusually for the time, 
the Celts believed in reincarnation— that they would be reborn on Earth 
to live and feast and fight again, which may have contributed 
to their fearlessness in battle. Some of them fought naked, 
scoffing at their enemies’ armor. The greatest trophy a Celtic warrior
could possess was the severed head of a foe. They preserved these heads 
in jars of cedar oil and showed them to guests 
who visited their homes. Celtic warriors were so valued 
in the ancient world that foreign kings often hired 
them as mercenary soldiers to serve in their armies. But the Celts were much more 
than just warriors. Among them were many skilled craftsmen,
artists, and great poets called bards. The bards sang of the brave deeds 
of their ancestors and praised the accomplishments
of warrior kings— and composed biting satires 
about cowardly or selfish leaders. The Celts worshipped many gods, and priests known as druids 
oversaw this worship. Anyone could become a druid, but the training required many years 
of study and memorization— the druids were not allowed to record
any of their teachings in writing. Druids supervised religious practices 
and sacrifices to the gods, but they were also teachers, healers, 
judges, and scientists. They were so respected that they could
step between warring tribes in the middle of a battle 
and call an end to the fighting. No Celt would dare to harm a druid,
or question their decisions. In the 2nd century BCE, the Romans 
began to encroach on Celtic territory, conquering the tribes of northern Italy. Rather than unite against the Roman 
legions in response to this defeat, the Celts maintained 
their tribal divisions. The tribes of Spain fell soon after. In the 1st century BCE, Julius Caesar 
marched his armies across France, using bribery, threats, and lies 
to turn tribes against each other. Only in the closing days of this great war did the Celts unite 
against their common enemy under the leadership 
of king Vercingetorix, but it was too late. Countless warriors and their families 
died or were enslaved as the Romans conquered France. Protected by the surrounding waters, the Celtic tribes of Britain and Ireland
were the last holdouts. When the Romans finally invaded Britain, the queen Boudicca united her tribe 
in a revolt after her husband was killed. She almost succeeded in driving 
the Roman legions out of Britain before dying as she led a final battle 
against the enemy. By the end of the 1st century CE, 
Ireland alone, far out at sea, remained unconquered by Rome. There, the ways of the ancient Celts 
survived untouched by the outside world long after Rome itself lay in ruins.

Correct Option: B

survived untouched by the outside world long after Rome itself lay in ruins.

to turn tribes against each other. Only in the closing days of this great war did the Celts unite 
against their common enemy under the leadership 
of king Vercingetorix, but it was too late. Countless warriors and their families 
died or were enslaved as the Romans conquered France. Protected by the surrounding waters, the Celtic tribes of Britain and Ireland
were the last holdouts. When the Romans finally invaded Britain, the queen Boudicca united her tribe 
in a revolt after her husband was killed. She almost succeeded in driving 
the Roman legions out of Britain before dying as she led a final battle 
against the enemy. By the end of the 1st century CE, 
Ireland alone, far out at sea, remained unconquered by Rome. There, the ways of the ancient Celts 
survived untouched by the outside world long after Rome itself lay in ruins.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was one part of the Celtic world not conquered by the Romans?
Options: A. Northern Italy, B. Spain, C. Ireland, D. Gaul (France)
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Alexander the Great resting when a band of strangers approached his camp in 335 BCE? Options: A. By the Danube River, B. In the Alps, C. In Asia Minor, D. On the Atlantic islands of Britain and Ireland Correct Option: A
Question 2: What did the Celts believe in that may have contributed to their fearlessness in battle? Options: A. The power of their gods, B. The strength of their warrior-kings, C. Reincarnation, or being reborn on Earth to live and fight again, D. The importance of preserving the heads of their enemies Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the role of the bards in Celtic society? Options: A. They were skilled craftsmen and artists, B. They were great poets who sang of the brave deeds of their ancestors and praised the accomplishments of warrior kings, C. They were druids who oversaw worship and supervised religious practices, D. They were mercenary soldiers who fought in foreign armies Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the significance of the severed head of a foe to a Celtic warrior? Options: A. It was a symbol of their strength and bravery, B. It was a trophy that they preserved in jars of cedar oil and showed to guests, C. It was a reminder of their fearlessness in battle, D. It was a way to honor their ancestors Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did the druids supervise religious practices and sacrifices to the gods? Options: A. They recorded their teachings in writing and passed them down to future generations, B. They memorized their teachings and passed them down orally, C. They used their knowledge of science and healing to guide their decisions, D. They relied on the guidance of the warrior-kings Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the outcome of the Roman conquest of France in the 1st century BCE? Options: A. The Celts united under the leadership of king Vercingetorix and defeated the Romans, B. The Celts maintained their tribal divisions and were conquered by the Romans, C. The Romans were driven out of France by the Celtic tribes, D. The Celts and Romans formed an alliance and coexisted peacefully Correct Option: B
Question 7: Who united her tribe in a revolt against the Roman legions in Britain? Options: A. Queen Boudicca, B. King Vercingetorix, C. Alexander the Great, D. Julius Caesar Correct Option: A
Question 8: What was the result of the Roman invasion of Britain, and how did it affect the Celtic tribes? Options: A. The Celts were able to drive the Romans out and maintain their independence, B. The Romans conquered Britain, but the Celtic tribes were able to preserve their way of life, C. The Romans conquered Britain, and many Celtic warriors and their families died or were enslaved, D. The Celts and Romans formed an alliance and coexisted peacefully Correct Option: C
Question 9: Which of the following best describes the social structure of the ancient Celts? Options: A. They were a unified empire with a single ruler, B. They were hundreds of independent tribes with their own warrior-kings and religious centers, C. They were a nomadic people with no fixed settlements or social hierarchy, D. They were a matriarchal society with women holding positions of power Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the significance of Ireland's geographical location in terms of its relationship with the Roman Empire? Options: A. It made Ireland vulnerable to Roman conquest, B. It allowed Ireland to remain unconquered by Rome due to its isolation, C. It facilitated trade and cultural exchange between Ireland and Rome, D. It led to Ireland becoming a Roman province Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was Set the god of...
Options: A. Warfare, B. The underworld, C. The harvest
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who organized the extravagant feast in Egypt, and what was the centerpiece of the occasion? Options: A. Osiris organized the feast, and the centerpiece was a beautiful golden throne., B. Set and his wife Nephtys organized the feast, and the centerpiece was a beautiful wooden chest., C. Isis organized the feast, and the centerpiece was a beautiful cedar tree., D. The king of Byblos organized the feast, and the centerpiece was a beautiful papyrus boat. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the real intention behind Set's announcement of a game at the feast? Options: A. To entertain the guests and create a joyful atmosphere., B. To find the perfect owner for the beautiful wooden chest., C. To trap his brother Osiris and get rid of him., D. To showcase his wealth and power to the foreign monarchs. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What happened to the coffin containing Osiris's body after it was tossed into the Nile? Options: A. It sank to the bottom of the river and was never found., B. It was carried by the Nile to the palace of Byblos, where it was discovered by the king., C. It drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, where a great cedar grew around it., D. It was retrieved by Set and hidden in a secret location. Correct Option: C
Question 4: How did Isis and Nephtys work together to find Osiris, and what disguises did they use? Options: A. They traveled as themselves, asking people about Osiris's whereabouts., B. They took the shape of falcons and traveled far and wide, gathering information., C. They disguised themselves as servants and infiltrated the palace of Byblos., D. They used magic to locate Osiris and did not need disguises. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was Isis's plan to make the baby prince of Byblos immortal, and how did the queen react to it? Options: A. Isis planned to bathe the child in the waters of the Nile, but the queen refused to let her do it., B. Isis planned to feed the child ambrosia, but the queen was skeptical about its effectiveness., C. Isis planned to bathe the child in flame, but the horrified queen intervened and stopped her., D. Isis planned to take the child to the realm of the dead, but the queen would not allow it. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What happened to Osiris's body after Isis recovered it from the tree and brought it back to Egypt? Options: A. She was able to resurrect him, and he returned to his position as ruler of Egypt., B. Set found the body and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt., C. The body was taken by the gods to the realm of the dead, where Osiris became the ruler., D. The body was hidden in a secret location, where it remained until the end of time. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did Isis ultimately recover the pieces of Osiris's dismembered body, and what was the one piece she could not find? Options: A. She used magic to locate the pieces and recovered all of them, including his penis., B. She traveled in a boat of papyrus, tracking down each piece, but could not find his heart., C. She enlisted the help of other gods, who found all the pieces except for his penis., D. She searched all over the land, traveling in a boat of papyrus, but could not find his penis, which a fish had eaten. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the consequence of Osiris's incomplete resurrection, and what role did he ultimately take on? Options: A. He was able to return to his position as ruler of Egypt, but with limited powers., B. He became the ruler of a neighboring kingdom, but not Egypt., C. He had to rule over Duat, the realm of the dead, instead of returning to the world of the living., D. He was relegated to a minor role among the gods, with little power or influence. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the significance of the child conceived by Osiris and Isis before he departed for the realm of the dead? Options: A. The child was a symbol of their love, but had no special destiny or role to play., B. The child was meant to be a sacrifice to the gods, ensuring Osiris's safe passage to the afterlife., C. The child was the chosen one, destined to avenge Osiris's death and reclaim his rightful place as ruler of Egypt., D. The child was a demigod, with special powers and abilities, but no specific role or destiny. Correct Option: C
Question 10: Evaluate the character of Set in the story. What motivated his actions, and what do his decisions reveal about his personality? Options: A. Set was motivated by a desire for justice and fairness, and his actions demonstrate his strong sense of morality., B. Set was driven by jealousy and a lust for power, and his decisions reveal his ruthless and cunning nature., C. Set was a complex character with mixed motivations, sometimes acting out of love and loyalty, and other times out of self-interest., D. Set was a minor character with little impact on the story, and his actions are largely irrelevant to the plot. Correct Option: B

It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was used to imprison Osiris?
Options: A. A golden cage, B. An ornate coffin, C. A sealed cave
Correct Option: B

Set was motivated by a desire for justice and fairness, and his actions demonstrate his strong sense of morality., B. Set was driven by jealousy and a lust for power, and his decisions reveal his ruthless and cunning nature., C. Set was a complex character with mixed motivations, sometimes acting out of love and loyalty, and other times out of self-interest., D. Set was a minor character with little impact on the story, and his actions are largely irrelevant to the plot. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where did Isis finally find Osiris’s body?
Options: A. Cairo, B. Byblos, C. Greece
Correct Option: B

The king of Byblos organized the feast, and the centerpiece was a beautiful papyrus boat. Correct Option: B

The body was taken by the gods to the realm of the dead, where Osiris became the ruler., D. The body was hidden in a secret location, where it remained until the end of time. Correct Option: B

She enlisted the help of other gods, who found all the pieces except for his penis., D. She searched all over the land, traveling in a boat of papyrus, but could not find his penis, which a fish had eaten. Correct Option: D

It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis

Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Devil’s Grandmother helped the youth by transforming into a
Options: A. Bat, B. Teacup, C. Black ant, D. Spider
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the prediction made by the townsfolk about the newborn son? Options: A. He would become a king, B. He would marry a princess, C. He would have a long life, D. He would be very wealthy Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the king's intention when he entrusted the youth with a letter for the queen? Options: A. To invite the youth to the palace for a celebration, B. To inform the queen about the youth's origins, C. To instruct the queen to arrange a wedding, D. To order the youth's execution Correct Option: D
Question 3: If you were in the youth's shoes, how would you handle the situation when the villagers asked you questions about the well and the tree? Options: A. I would try to answer their questions immediately, B. I would promise to answer their questions when I return, C. I would refuse to answer their questions, D. I would ask them for help in exchange for answering their questions Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the significance of the devil's grandmother in the story? Options: A. She was the one who helped the youth on his journey, B. She was the one who tried to harm the youth, C. She was the one who provided the youth with the three golden hairs, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: What was the solution to the ferryman's problem, according to the devil's dream? Options: A. He should continue paddling through the black water, B. He should hand his oars to a willing passenger, C. He should take a break from his task, D. He should ask for help from the villagers Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the reason for the tree being barren, according to the youth? Options: A. It was due to the lack of water, B. It was due to the presence of a mouse gnawing at its root, C. It was due to the absence of sunlight, D. It was due to the poor soil quality Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did the king's plan ultimately backfire? Options: A. The youth failed to retrieve the three golden hairs, B. The king's daughter refused to marry the youth, C. The king became trapped in his own scheme and ended up as the ferryman's replacement, D. The youth and the princess eloped without the king's knowledge Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the outcome of the youth's journey to Hell? Options: A. He failed to retrieve the three golden hairs, B. He retrieved the three golden hairs but lost his way back, C. He retrieved the three golden hairs and gained valuable information, D. He got stuck in Hell forever Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be inferred about the king's character from the story? Options: A. He was kind and benevolent, B. He was cunning and power-hungry, C. He was wise and just, D. He was weak and indecisive Correct Option: B
Question 10: What moral lesson can be derived from the story? Options: A. That greed and power can lead to one's downfall, B. That kindness and compassion can lead to success, C. That intelligence and wit can help overcome challenges, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the Devil's Grandmother helping the youth by transforming into a specific object or creature. However, none of the generated MCQs mention the Devil's Grandmother transforming into anything.

That being said, the generated MCQ that comes closest to mentioning the Devil's Grandmother's role in helping the youth is:

She was the one who provided the youth with the three golden hairs, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The baby’s distinguishing birthmark predicted that he would:
Options: A. Travel to hell and back, B. Marry a princess, C. Kill a king, D. Be rich beyond his wildest dreams
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the prediction made by the townsfolk about the newborn son? Options: A. He would become a king, B. He would marry a princess, C. He would have a long life, D. He would be very wealthy Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the king's intention when he entrusted the youth with a letter for the queen? Options: A. To invite the youth to the palace for a celebration, B. To inform the queen about the youth's origins, C. To instruct the queen to arrange a wedding, D. To order the youth's execution Correct Option: D
Question 3: If you were in the youth's shoes, how would you handle the situation when the villagers asked you questions about the well and the tree? Options: A. I would try to answer their questions immediately, B. I would promise to answer their questions when I return, C. I would refuse to answer their questions, D. I would ask them for help in exchange for answering their questions Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the significance of the devil's grandmother in the story? Options: A. She was the one who helped the youth on his journey, B. She was the one who tried to harm the youth, C. She was the one who provided the youth with the three golden hairs, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: What was the solution to the ferryman's problem, according to the devil's dream? Options: A. He should continue paddling through the black water, B. He should hand his oars to a willing passenger, C. He should take a break from his task, D. He should ask for help from the villagers Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the reason for the tree being barren, according to the youth? Options: A. It was due to the lack of water, B. It was due to the presence of a mouse gnawing at its root, C. It was due to the absence of sunlight, D. It was due to the poor soil quality Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did the king's plan ultimately backfire? Options: A. The youth failed to retrieve the three golden hairs, B. The king's daughter refused to marry the youth, C. The king became trapped in his own scheme and ended up as the ferryman's replacement, D. The youth and the princess eloped without the king's knowledge Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the outcome of the youth's journey to Hell? Options: A. He failed to retrieve the three golden hairs, B. He retrieved the three golden hairs but lost his way back, C. He retrieved the three golden hairs and gained valuable information, D. He got stuck in Hell forever Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be inferred about the king's character from the story? Options: A. He was kind and benevolent, B. He was cunning and power-hungry, C. He was wise and just, D. He was weak and indecisive Correct Option: B
Question 10: What moral lesson can be derived from the story? Options: A. That greed and power can lead to one's downfall, B. That kindness and compassion can lead to success, C. That intelligence and wit can help overcome challenges, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

Options: A. Adopted the child, B. Sent orders for the child to be killed, C. Went to see the child for himself, D. Shut his daughter away
Correct Option: B

freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: After visiting the devil's grandmother, the youth discovered that the village well was dry because
Options: A. there was an enormous toad blocking the well, B. of seasonal drought, C. the villagers over-consumed water
Correct Option: A

He retrieved the three golden hairs and gained valuable information, D. He got stuck in Hell forever Correct Option: C
